"THE ART AND CRAFT OF EMBROIDERY\
A Hand-Book for Embroiderers\
CONTENTS\

16. Updates"

"INTRODUCTORY NOTES\
\
Embroidery is pre-eminent among the decorative arts -- all persons wear clothes, and thus the decorative quality of clothing is the most often encountered artistic facet of daily life. Embroiderers may apply various symbols and decorative effects to most clothing items -- shirts, pants, skirts and gowns, as well as footwear, handwear and headwear of all kinds. Over seventy unique symbol patterns are available to the most skilled embroiderers."

"RELATED CRAFTS\
\
Not all items will succumb to the embroiderer's needle. Jewelry, weapons and most other metal items require the services of an ENGRAVER; stationery is the specialty of the EMBOSSER; and bodily adornment is the province of the TATOOIST. An embroiderer with skill in one or more of these auxiliary crafts will find more fortune and fame in his or her career."

"MEASURES OF PROFICIENCY\
\
Ten levels of proficiency are commonly recognized for the embroiderer's skill:\
\
1. Novice\
2. Junior Apprentice\
3. Senior Apprentice\
4. Fellowcraft\
5. Journeyman\
6. Artisan\
7. Senior Artisan\
8. Master\
9. Master Adept\
10. Grand Master\
\
A Novice embroiderer possesses very limited ability, and is able to attempt only a few rudimentary symbols, while a seasoned Master may command dozens of decorative options.\
\
The remainder of this hand-book describes the symbols available to embroiderers at each level of proficiency."

"NOVICE\
\
Novices are the least experienced class of embroiderers. Their decorative options are admittedly rather plain and utilitarian.\
\
They may apply various symbols to clothing items, such as the dot, line, mark, squiggle, smileyface, or the potato."

"JUNIOR APPRENTICE\
\
Junior Apprentices know a bit more than Novices, but their improved efforts can hardly be called impressive.\
\
The symbols which they might employ include the square, circle, triangle, heart, star, moon, sun, key, leaf, and the eye."

"SENIOR APPRENTICE\
\
Senior Apprentices have attained sufficient skill to apply a handful of modest but attractive symbols.\
\
At this level of skill, they can confidently depict a flower, dove, owl, duck, fish, hare, ermine, cat, rat, boat, kite, chair, plume, or rose."

"FELLOWCRAFT\
\
Fellowcraft embroiderers have spent many hours learning their trade, and may apply a personal mark onto items embellished by their skill.\
\
They can embroider a clef, quill, mask, thistle, anchor, tankard, hourglass, tree, needle, plow, scroll, paintbrush, or a crow."

"JOURNEYMAN\
\
Journeymen possess the confidence to work with symbols of unique appeal and significance.\
\
The range of symbols they employ encompasses the sword, hammer, fist, skull, thunderbolt, serpent, dagger, scythe, and raven."

"ARTISAN\
\
Artisans are capable of the fine control needed to produce some of the more challenging and beautiful depictions of fierce beasts.\
\
Symbols they might employ are the stag, lion, bull, bear, eagle, boar, wolf, horse, fox, swan, monkey, or walrus."

"SENIOR ARTISAN\
\
Senior Artisans are sought by those desiring rare and exotic symbols for their possessions. They often serve as assistants to Master embroiderers.\
\
They might employ the trefoil, quatrefoil, cinquefoil, caduceus, lyre, compass, palette, spinningwheel, loom, or rose-vine."

"MASTER\
\
Masters are the virtuosi of the embroiderer's art. Their long career of study and craftsmanship has brought them the ability to work with complex symbols requiring great skill to execute. They can also alter the embroidered symbols of items that have previously been worked.\
\
The fierce heraldic animals -- gryphon, unicorn, wyvern, phoenix, manticore, or basilisk -- can be depicted by a Master's art."

"MASTER ADEPT\
\
Master Adepts have spent countless seasons practicing their skills, and are usually the most skilled embroiderers within the Castle. They can create certain symbols of exceptional difficulty and depth of meaning -- the dragon, and the castle."

"GRAND MASTER\
\
Only rarely is there a Grand Master of the embroidery art within the Castle. When these experts appear, their creations are almost entirely at the order of Her Majesty and the Court. Only Grand Masters may apply the Royal emblem of the triflame to items; the lesser symbol of the snowflake is also within their skill."

"SUMPTUARY RESTRICTIONS\
\
Embroiderers are expected to conform to Chapter III, Title II, paragraph 11 of the Queen's Capitulary, which forbids the false display of badges or emblems; they should also avoid becoming accessories to violations of this law by creating or embroidering badges for persons not entitled to them. If found guilty, violators of Chapter III, Title II, paragraph 11 of the Queen's Capitulary can be exposed for no more than two days in the public stocks, or suffer no more than four days imprisonment."

"UPDATES\
\
Embroiderers, illustrators and other artists within the Castle are continuously creating new symbols that may be applied to fabrics. The text of this book will mysteriously update itself as new choices become available; embroiderers with higher skills will inform you if and when updates occur.\
\
Please bring typographical errors or other textual problems found in this volume to the attention of the staff."
